results.content: I have been hearing about Microfrontends for  a while now but never really dug into how they work. This course is a great introduction to the architectural pattern that includes concrete examples of how to implement it and the problems a developer may face along the way. I have taken a few of Stephen Grider's courses and his teaching style is clear and comprehensive.
results.content_html: I have been hearing about Microfrontends for a while now but never really dug into how they work. This course is a great introduction to the architectural pattern that includes concrete examples of how to implement it and the problems a developer may face along the way. I have taken a few of Stephen Grider's courses and his teaching style is clear and comprehensive.

results.content: Generally a good course. I'd be happier if the various assets -- and there are a lot of them -- were in source control rather than the endless set of zip files we have. Also, the Q/A is getting neglected, and if it's at all possible for Stephen, it would be good if it got more attention.
results.content_html: Generally a good course. I'd be happier if the various assets -- and there are a lot of them -- were in source control rather than the endless set of zip files we have. Also, the Q/A is getting neglected, and if it's at all possible for Stephen, it would be good if it got more attention.

results.content: The most practical and readily usable course on micro frontend architecture currently available - covered in Stephen's signature comprehensive and thoughtful delivery that leaves no gaps in understanding. I was afraid that this would be React specific but no, the concepts are covered in a general sense and Stephen demonstrates how to build isolated front-end app components in frameworks like Vue.js. I really appreciated the extensive coverage of Webpack 5 and module federation as well.
results.content_html: The most practical and readily usable course on micro frontend architecture currently available - covered in Stephen's signature comprehensive and thoughtful delivery that leaves no gaps in understanding. I was afraid that this would be React specific but no, the concepts are covered in a general sense and Stephen demonstrates how to build isolated front-end app components in frameworks like Vue.js. I really appreciated the extensive coverage of Webpack 5 and module federation as well.

results.content: Another great course by Stephen Grider.  Stephen has done a great job of finding the most effective way of implementing microfrontends and deep-diving it, even though it is one of the more complex ones.  I am a senior lead software engineer and system architect for a mature SaaS company, tasked with converting a large monolith PHP webapp into serverless React with microservice backends and microfrontends.  This course will save me a lot of time in R&D learning how to stitch together the front end!
results.content_html: Another great course by Stephen Grider. Stephen has done a great job of finding the most effective way of implementing microfrontends and deep-diving it, even though it is one of the more complex ones. I am a senior lead software engineer and system architect for a mature SaaS company, tasked with converting a large monolith PHP webapp into serverless React with microservice backends and microfrontends. This course will save me a lot of time in R&D learning how to stitch together the front end!

results.content: As usual, Stephen Grider delivers quality courses. Documented, with graphical explanations, thorough. I've learned more with Stephen than with any other teacher on online-courses websites. The only two things Stephen is "missing" is a progression path for  his course (I.e : do course 1, than 2 etc. to become good at XYZ) and a timestamp for the latest update of a course. For the rest, it's magic.
results.content_html: As usual, Stephen Grider delivers quality courses. Documented, with graphical explanations, thorough. I've learned more with Stephen than with any other teacher on online-courses websites. The only two things Stephen is "missing" is a progression path for his course (I.e : do course 1, than 2 etc. to become good at XYZ) and a timestamp for the latest update of a course. For the rest, it's magic.

results.content:
I saw the Authentication section and was expecting some guidance on how to manage the authentication information - where to store credentials and how to pass it between the apps to be used to make external calls. 

Other than that, I believe this course touched on every important factor to creating an app with microfrontends. The pacing was perfect to gradually bring together the various concepts.

results.content: One of the best courses I have taken so far on Udemy. You'll end up with a general idea of ​​how MFEs work and the considerations to keep in mind when working with them. In any case, it's a totally recomendable course, direct and focused in one theme.

results.content: Excellent course. I really enjoyed it. I have a fair bit of experience with microservices in the backend, so naturally was curious about microfrontends and how they might apply to that architecture. I did some initial research and decided it was not worth pursuing. However, I saw this course and have enjoyed Stephen's courses in the past, so decided it was worth the investment of time.  Sure enough, I now feel pretty confident to go ahead and apply the lessons here and see what I can build on my own. Stephen tames complexity like few others can.  Good job!
results.content_html: Excellent course. I really enjoyed it. Sure enough, I now feel pretty confident to go ahead and apply the lessons here and see what I can build on my own. Stephen tames complexity like few others can. Good job!

results.content: Another amazing course from Stephen Grider. I buy his courses without hesitation knowing I will get more than my moneys worth, learning a ton and having fun along the way. Pro tip #1: Never skip his optional videos. They are PACKED with the type of content you really want: deep dives into complex topics, breaking them down into child's play so when you run into it in the real world it's basically a non-issue. Pro tip #2: Buy every course he has, do them all twice.

results.content: Stephen Grider's courses always teach something new and you would end up as a better developer by the time you finish the course. This course is no different. There are very few resources available on Micro frontends. This is the best. You will get a clear idea of dos and don'ts when you work on the Micro frontend. The best part of his course is the time and energy he spends on explaining the concepts and architecture. You can always understand the code. But what's important is why the code is written the way it's written and Stephen does that so beautifully. Like all his earlier course I enjoyed and learnt a lot in this course. Thank you stephen. You are the best

results.content:
It was nice but I had prefered to see it using typescript.
Moreover, the e-commerce example at the start was nice and it would have been great to continue on it.
By example, how to select a product and add it on a cart that is not on the same micro fontend ?
A section on tests should have been nice too.

Finally, a complete training (maybe another one ?) on micro frontends and microservices using Graphql and typescript seems to be the best 2021 solution. Should be nice to work on it.

results.content:
Stephen Grider is an exceptional educator. This course provides deep hands-on learning, and improved my confidence in working with Webpack Module Federation. I appreciate that he dedicates time to explain the gotchas as well as his rationale for architecting the Microfrontends.

One area for improvement would be updating ~2 videos to fix some existing bugs. Check out the Q&A for solutions if you encounter them.

I have completed several of Stephen's courses, and they have all been excellent. This course is just as excellent and I highly recommend it!
results.content_html:
Stephen Grider is an exceptional educator. This course provides deep hands-on learning, and improved my confidence in working with Webpack Module Federation. I appreciate that he dedicates time to explain the gotchas as well as his rationale for architecting the Microfrontends.

One area for improvement would be updating ~2 videos to fix some existing bugs. Check out the Q&A for solutions if you encounter them.

I have completed several of Stephen's courses, and they have all been excellent. This course is just as excellent and I highly recommend it!

results.content:
If you wish to gain a huge jumpstart on learning Webpack 5 federation and building microfrontend apps, this course represents the current bible for best practices for achieving true segregated team development of federated apps. 

The final app is an amazingly clear representation of the possibilities associated with Webpack 5 federation and microfrontends.
results.content_html:
If you wish to gain a huge jumpstart on learning Webpack 5 federation and building microfrontend apps, this course represents the current bible for best practices for achieving true segregated team development of federated apps.

The final app is an amazingly clear representation of the possibilities associated with Webpack 5 federation and microfrontends.

results.content: Definitely disappointed about the authentication or the lack of it. The titles of the lessons in that section are pure click-bite. Also,  can't see a particular reason why there is no example of component that uses some kind of API for data. There are some interesting topics discussed in this course but trivial for experienced developers.

results.content: Overall a really good walkthrough of what to consider when using Microfrontends and Module Federation. I had some issues though, in a few videos where I had to do some workarounds and look through the Q&A to get it to work correctly. Would also be appreciated if we got to see how you would set up the project with the "Distributed Repo approach", so that we can compare the amount of setup needed for the "Distributed Repo" and "Monorepo" approach.
results.content_html: Overall a really good walkthrough of what to consider when using Microfrontends and Module Federation. I had some issues though, in a few videos where I had to do some workarounds and look through the Q&A to get it to work correctly. Would also be appreciated if we got to see how you would set up the project with the "Distributed Repo approach", so that we can compare the amount of setup needed for the "Distributed Repo" and "Monorepo" approach.

results.content: Great course! It covers the basic and advanced stuff related to microfrontends. I liked that the course started with explaining the basic on a simple project and then continued with advanced features in another one. A very good introduction to microfrontends and challenges one will encounter when implementing them. Highly recommended!

A very good introduction to microfrontends and challenges one will encounter when implementing them. Highly recommended!

results.content: Stephen is an awesome instructor, I have taken many of his courses. This one was good, I would like to have seen more around managing state (e.g. Redux) in the sub applications and more information about sharing state between apps (e.g. user information, such as user ID / security token, which all apps are going to need), but overall, I learned a whole lot and I have a great foundation to build on top of. Thanks Stephen!
results.content_html: Stephen is an awesome instructor, I have taken many of his courses. This one was good, I would like to have seen more around managing state (e.g. Redux) in the sub applications and more information about sharing state between apps (e.g. user information, such as user ID / security token, which all apps are going to need), but overall, I learned a whole lot and I have a great foundation to build on top of. Thanks Stephen!

results.content: Great introduction course to microfrontends! I wish there were more real life aspects covered in this course such as shared state and business logic among apps not just passing callbacks
results.content_html: Great introduction course to microfrontends! I wish there were more real life aspects covered in this course such as shared state and business logic among apps not just passing callbacks

results.content:
It was something new for me and I did enjoyed a lot of things through out the course.
If you are not from a React Background, this course will be a little difficult for you. But in the end you are going to learn about microfrontends and the challenges involved.
I must say, a brilliant concept and a brilliant course on it if you are thinking to get some knowledge on it.

results.content: Basically I autobuy any course by Stephen, and he doesn't disappoint again. Our company is about to implement microfrontends, and this course has become our starting point. We will implement a lot of the things Stephen teaches here, starting from the fact that we also do run-time integration. I'll edit this as I go along.

We will implement a lot of the things Stephen teaches here, starting from the fact that we also do run-time integration. I'll edit this as I go along.

Wow! Amazing course with so much to learn. The concepts were very well explained by the instructor.
Understanding the Implementation of multi tier navigation was a bit hard to understand initially, but if you practise and follow the instructions step by step things will fall in place eventually.

results.content: As I experienced with all of Stephen Griders Courses it is well prepared, easy to follow , exciting and cover a lot of great Ideas as well as caveats around the Topic!

results.content:
The course is as good as any. 

However my problem is that I found it too opinionated. Teaches and works only to work in a specific way. I would have hoped for more generic approach here. Still not clear about stuff like how state can be shared amongst child apps, for example, while using a redux state management library.

But as always, Stephen rocks, and this is one more feather to his hat.
results.content_html:
The course is as good as any.

However my problem is that I found it too opinionated. Teaches and works only to work in a specific way. I would have hoped for more generic approach here. Still not clear about stuff like how state can be shared amongst child apps, for example, while using a redux state management library.

But as always, Stephen rocks, and this is one more feather to his hat.
